how would you describe your main use cas: Note-taking;Task and project management (including CRMs);As a knowledge base (including technical, non-fiction and encyclopaedic content)
do you share your tiddlywiki(s) with oth: No, but I may export content into other formats and share individual tiddlers, the whole wiki, or an extract of the wiki
putting it all together, what value does: It provides me a unified note and knowledgebase system, with some built-in smarts (basically, being a wiki), and the ability to add additional smarts as required.
what is your level of ability with tiddl: I have customised TiddlyWiki through options and plugins;I have written custom CSS styles
how do you back up/sync changes between: Web or cloud hosting (other than TiddlyHost/TiddlySpot e.g. Netlify, AWS, OVH, Google Cloud...);DIY (any other solution)
as you selected diy, would be grateful f: DIY web solution for my main personal TW. I run node locally (in a VM), and on that VM I also run nginx as a reverse proxy to the node TW. nginx handles authentication. hen my home router port forwards back to that nginx frontend. This allows me access from anywhere online

outside of plugins, palettes and other i:
I've tweaked many elements of the interface (sidebar item arrangement, tagpill menu items, order of items when viewing a tid). However the overall effect remains that of TW out-of-the-box to the casual observer. 

Vague plan to organise these into an edition at some time
what are we doing well? prompts for thin:
I enjoy it's a friendly and welcoming community. I think being a small community is part of that (small community caveat, see next question). 

I'm excited for the MWS, as a true design-for-online/multiuser system will suit at least one future project, possibly more.
what could we do better? prompts for thi:
I think the "out of the box" experience of TW is poor. The concepts are great, but the initial user experience of setting it up (fighting browser security with single file, or setting up node, or tiddlyhost solutions) is a high first step. 

Small community is indicative of a project that isn't really growing, and IMHO not reaching it's potential. Small community means limited users and testers, many of whom are happy to solve problems - but not indicative of the broader userbase
with your consent, we would like to publ: Yes, I am happy for my responses to be published
